title: Can the ARAM format be changed already?
body:
Personally, playing ARAM is the most fun part about this game as I've gotten burnt out from playing ranked, but it feels like I'm being punished for playing it too much. What I mean by that is that I'm matched with all ARAM accounts now. I see the same OP ARAM champs in every single game I play and games are so stompy. I'm fine with losing ARAMs because sometimes it's not under our control, since it is supposed to be "all random", but it's not random. It's a bunch of accounts, with OP champs on there, who get a pick of the litter of an abusive champ in ARAM. So, why can't every champion be unlocked,  and have "All Random, All Mid" be truly random? Am I missing something here? I'm fed up with it at this point and cannot see how the negatives of this be worse than what ARAM is now.

Edit: I've read all your comments and I appreciate the discussion going on here. Unlocking all of the champions may be a little too drastic, or maybe not, but I personally like the idea. In the end, I do think there needs to be some sort of change, whether or not my proposed idea is that change. Some people are worried about getting champs they're unfamiliar with, but isn't it just as likely that the enemy team will get champions they're unfamiliar with too? I personally think it's okay if, in some games, you get an unfamiliar champ because at least it's TRUELY RANDOM. Bite the bullet and move on. That's just my two cents; Keep this going so hopefully someone from Riot can reply on this topic :)

replies.body: This has been suggested before. Its not BS, nor is it cheating the system.

I have all champions unlocked. I play mostly ARAM - 1309 wins and 1258 losses. The champ select is NOT random, because if it was, you would see mirror matches from time to time. I dont think ive seen a mirror since the early days.

Okay, so other than mirrors not being there (intentionally), what proof do you have that it's not random?
because if mirrors are disabled its not random 5 champs for your team
With that exception, what else is there? You seemed to imply that it was completely non-random, but only really have one reason.
Just because the events are mutally exclusive(meaning no champ appears more than once in this case), does not mean it's not random....

I think you need to read the definition of mutually exclusive and random in terms of statistics (which this is, since it is supposedly "random" as pulling numbers out of a hat). 

And my point is that RIot already screwed with what "random" means. Random could mean what the community meant it to mean (as ARAM is a community creation) as to a randomly chosen champion on your team. Or you can do what Riot did and add limitations. 

Once the limitations are in, then its no longer a simple random sample. And as its no longer a simple random sample, you can limit the champions that will be picked to the ones the player owns, and it will still be considered "random". Once you stop using a simple random sample, you can stratify the picks however you want and call it a random sampling with X limitations - which is what Riot did.
Are you implying that picking numbers out of a hat without replacing them isn't random?

i'm not native englishspeaking, so i might lack the right wording here i guess, as normally mutually exclusive would mean you can get A **or** B, but not both at once...

However, what i meant is, useing the pulling numbers out of a hat as example, the current system does not throw numbers back in a fter they have been pulled, which is why i added the part in () to hopefully make my point clear.

however, just because the stochastic formula changes a bit makes it no less random. And even with mirrormatches it still wouldn't be the 'simple random sample', as it still is limited to each champ only once per team.
For the 'simple random sample', it needs to also to be possible of haveing the same champion multiple times per team, which would mean a potential one for all, even if the chances are incredible low.

However you're right in that drawing from the full champ pool would not make it 'more randome' or 'truely random'.
It still is a good idea to let it draw from the full pool, as it would no longer be biased based on individuel champion pools.

Useing the very simplified model of 'pulling numbers out of a hat' for current aram, people draw numbers out off different hats that contain different numbers, and if we asume that the 'win' condition is getting the highest number, those that have a higher average in their respective hat do have a higher probabillity of winning.
To asure that the odds are equall amongst all participants, they all need to draw from the same hat, and if you want to go the full way, then either they do that smiultanously or the number gets thrown back into the hat

That's why champions like EZ or Lux are better for finishing off low hp targets hiding behind turrets.

If you are Karthus and waiting around for your ultimate to finish off people in ARAM, you're playing him wrong.

Karthus in ARAM is:
-Build only pure AP dmg and Magic Pen items (cdr not necessary).
-Snowball into enemy team (even if under tower, better if you can stay just out of range of it)
-Feel free to die. Just start spamming spells and damaging the enemy. 

Since the enemy cannot heal at base in this game mode, the damage sticks. As Karthus, you come back to lane with slightly better items, full health, and more damage. Most people do not balance their health pool in this game mode (a.k.a. - knowing when to die in ARAM). A lot of players will sit under their tower with less than 40% HP, sticking their head out every now and then to poke. Most champions will die doing this. Karthus loves it when people stay under turret, because he just snowballs in, dies, and then damages everyone around him.

Eventually, Karthus just outdamages everyone and everything (other than certain champs who poke from afar, like Lux).
